trustfund: TF027180-SECONDARY HEALTH CARE,TF022223-CANADIAN CTF FOR SUSTAINABLE DEV.-POP.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            with a likely sustainability, and high institutional
            development impacts. Although satisfactory, both
            performances were uneven, due to the difficult political
            climate which hindered implementation governance, and
            endangered staff livelihoods. Key lessons highlight the
            correct decision to appoint well-qualified sector, and
            procurement specialists, who strengthened the Resident
            Mission efforts in supporting, and organizing implementation
            clinics on procurement, and financial matters for the
            project implementation units (PIUs), greatly facilitating
            the success of the project. This technical know-how also
            provided a close working relationship with the client,
            essential for building capacities, and project
            restructuring. A possible supervision strategy is thus
            suggested, i.e., to contract local firms to train, and
            deploy supervision support teams, who would provide
            technical assistance to the state PIUs, and carry out site
            supervision as well, likely to ease budget constraints.
            Recommendations suggest that project design should ensure
            monitoring, and evaluation methods early on, so that
            measurable indicators may identify potential project
            adjustments. Additionally, complex arrangements, such as
            retailing project financing through participating financial
            intermediaries can be mitigated, preferably under the
            Project Preparation Facility, or grant financing.
